sections.text: Mina Park: Hi Eugene—Mina Park here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. Did I catch you at an okay time?
Eugene Ray: Hey Mina, yeah, I’ve got about five minutes before my next meeting. What’s up?

Mina Park: Perfect. I’ll keep it tight. I’m calling because a lot of beverage brands end up with the same problem: customer issues are coming in from Zendesk, chats, and even account notes—then the team tries to translate that into Jira, and it turns into a lot of duplicate triage and “is this the same thing?” debates. We built Issue_Tracker to sit between support and engineering and basically standardize the “issue object” so you can see the real themes, impacted customers, and status in one place. Curious—how are you handling that today at Oceanmint?

Eugene Ray: It’s… messy. Zendesk is the source, but a lot of context lives in Salesforce and in CSM notes. Then product gets a Jira ticket, but it’s hard to tell how widespread something really is. We end up chasing squeaky wheels.

Mina Park: That’s exactly the gap Issue_Tracker is designed for. The first thing it does is ingest the raw inputs—tickets, chats, emails, even summarized call notes—then it automatically deduplicates and clusters them using semantic similarity plus rules you can set, like product area, platform, severity, or keywords. So instead of 80 separate tickets about “promo code not applying,” you see one cluster with volume, top phrases, representative examples, and links back to each source record in Zendesk.
Eugene Ray: Okay, so it groups them. We’ve tried tagging, but it’s inconsistent.

Mina Park: Totally—tags rely on humans being perfect. The clustering is automated, but also controllable: you get naming suggestions for clusters, you can merge or split clusters with guardrails, and each cluster keeps structured fields like affected product area and suspected root cause category—bug vs UX vs missing feature vs integration. The impact is you stop underestimating issues that look small individually but are actually huge across many tickets.
Eugene Ray: That would help. One challenge is product doesn’t trust support labels, and support doesn’t know what engineering is doing.

Mina Park: Exactly. The second piece is the linkage downstream. Issue_Tracker doesn’t replace Jira—when you connect a cluster to a Jira ticket, it maintains that relationship and keeps status consistent across teams. So CSMs and support can see “this cluster is tied to JIRA-312, in progress,” and product can see the evidence and customer examples without digging through Zendesk.
Eugene Ray: What about follow-up? We’ve had cases where we fix something and only a few customers get notified.

Mina Park: Great point—that’s actually one of the most common use cases. CSMs can subscribe specific accounts—like a strategic account or a whole segment—to a relevant cluster. Then when the linked Jira ticket ships, Issue_Tracker records the release milestone and creates a history trail: which customers were impacted, which ones were notified, when, and with what message. So you can run consistent follow-up instead of relying on someone remembering to circle back.
Eugene Ray: That’s interesting. We’ve had painful moments where sales is mid-renewal and we’re scrambling for a status update.

Mina Park: Yep—and even if you’re not doing anything fancy, just having a defensible, searchable history of “why we prioritized this,” “who it affected,” and “what the current status is” reduces that scramble. Out of curiosity, how many tickets are you handling per week, roughly?
Eugene Ray: Support is probably 600–800 a week. A bunch are repeats, especially around integrations and promotions.

Mina Park: That’s a perfect volume for clustering to pay off quickly. Usually the first win is visibility: within a week or two, teams realize, “Oh, this is actually three big themes, not 200 random tickets,” and they stop duplicating triage. Second win is customer comms: CSMs know exactly who to update when a fix ships.
Eugene Ray: How heavy is the setup? I don’t want another six-month implementation.

Mina Park: Understood. For a first pass, it’s typically lightweight: connect Zendesk, connect Jira, map a few rules like product areas or severity terms, and decide who owns merge/split decisions for clusters. You can start with one queue or one product line, prove it out, then expand. The goal is to get value without boiling the ocean.
Eugene Ray: Who usually owns it—support ops, product ops?

Mina Park: It varies, but the sweet spot is a partnership: Support Ops or CX owns the inbound sources and workflows; Product Ops or an engineering triage lead owns the downstream mapping to Jira. The point is that the system keeps everyone aligned without requiring everyone to live in the same tool.
Eugene Ray: Sounds reasonable. Can it handle cases where one customer issue actually includes multiple problems?

Mina Park: Yes—that’s where the merge/split workflow helps. The model will suggest clusters, but if something is too broad, you split it into sub-issues with guardrails so you don’t create chaos. And because everything stays linked to source records, you can always click back to see the exact customer language and context.
Eugene Ray: Got it. What would you need from me to see if this fits?

Mina Park: The best next step is a quick 30-minute working session where we look at: your Zendesk structure, how Jira tickets are created today, and one or two recent “fire drill” issues—like an integration outage or promo problem. Then I can show you what clustering would have produced and how the subscription-and-notify workflow would look for your CSM team.
Eugene Ray: I’m open to that. I’d want our Support Ops manager involved, and maybe someone from product.

Mina Park: Perfect. If you tell me who those two people are, I’ll send a calendar invite with a simple agenda and a couple questions ahead of time—nothing heavy. Do you have time next week—Tuesday or Thursday?
Eugene Ray: Thursday morning is usually better. Maybe 10:00?

Mina Park: Thursday at 10:00 works. I’ll send an invite for 30 minutes. Before I do—one last quick check: if you could solve just one thing in this process, would it be reducing duplicate triage, or getting consistent customer follow-up when engineering ships?
Eugene Ray: Honestly, consistent follow-up. It hits retention and makes us look more coordinated.

Mina Park: Great—then I’ll tailor the session around the “subscribe accounts to clusters” workflow and the release milestone notifications, and we’ll also show how clustering reduces the noise feeding into that. I’ll email you shortly—who should I include besides you?
Eugene Ray: Add Priya in Support Ops and Dan from Product Ops. I’ll forward you their emails.
Mina Park: Perfect. Thanks Eugene—appreciate the time. I’ll get that on the calendar for Thursday at 10:00 and include a short pre-read.
Eugene Ray: Sounds good, Mina. Talk Thursday.
